thread.title: Clouding Up Trade Secret Protections

author: Winthrop & Weinstine, P.A.
title: Clouding Up Trade Secret Protections
text:

“The cloud” can refer to a lot of things, and is frequently a misunderstood concept. While cloud computing can encompass a number of Internet-based functions, in its simplest form, “the cloud” merely refers to the use of remote servers for data storage, processing, and management. Usually, the remote servers are hosted by a third party cloud service provider. The cloud service provider stores and maintains the physical servers that users access remotely. So essentially, cloud computing is the use of someone else’s server, located somewhere else, to do something on your local computer. Dropbox and Google Docs are common examples of cloud storage. A trade secret, as defined by the Uniform Trade Secrets Act, is information that is (1) secret; (2) valuable because it is secret; and (3) subject to reasonable efforts to maintain its secrecy. The Coca-Cola formula, for one. Disclosure of a trade secret to a third par 
So the question becomes: is a cloud service provider a third party? When a trade secret owner stores a trade secret in the cloud, and effectively “discloses” the information to the cloud service provider, has secrecy been lost? Courts have not had a chance to answer this definitively. The outcome may hinge on the often boilerplate Terms of Use agreements
